isis.stitle: DIAMONDLIFE™ (BOSCH PIN SLIDE) DISC BRAKES For Vehicles Built Before June 3, 2002 - install - CALIPER

svcprocinfo.para: During service procedure, keep grease and other foreign material away from caliper assembly, disc brake pads, brake rotor and external surfaces of hub. Handle parts carefully to avoid damage to caliper, rotor, disc brake pads and brake lines.
In the event the original disc brake pads are to be used again, use the markings made during removal, so that they are reinstalled in same location.

important.para:
If a new caliper assembly is being installed, be sure that the bleeder screw (Item 1, Figure 21)
is installed in Upper (top) hydraulic line port of caliper (Item 2, Figure 21) .

svcprocinfo.para: The following steps refer to only one wheel. The same procedure will need to be performed at each wheel.

svcsubproc.title: Install

note.para:
Several changes have been incorporated within the anchor plate assembly and caliper mounting bolts on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002. It is important to recognize that these changes are not found on disc brakes on vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, unless a complete rebuild of the anchor plate assembly was performed on the vehicle. The components that have changed are the leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 67)
and (Figure 68)
and caliper mounting bolts (Figure 71) .

caution.para:
When servicing vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, it is recommended that the old guide pins (Figure 67)
be replaced with the new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
that are used on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002. Because of the differences in guide pins effective with brakes used on vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002, any replacement of the guide pins should be done in pairs and the correct mounting bolts (Figure 71)
and torque must be used. Refer to CALIPER, Install
for proper torque requirements.

note.para:
If the old leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 67)
are being replaced with new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
as recommended below, it is NOT necessary to remove the anchor plate and splash shield from the vehicle to replace the guide pins.

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 66
for Items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para:
Before installing caliper, visually inspect anchor plate (Item 1) for damage or defects to mating surfaces at anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 2) and check guide pin heads (Item 3). If guide pin heads are the same (Figure 67) , the vehicle was manufactured before June 3, 2002. You can tell the old guide pins from the new guide pins by looking at the head of the guide pins. The old guide pin heads will look the same, the new trailing guide pin head will have a notch on each side of the rounded sides of the head. If the old guide pins are found, it is recommended that new leading and trailing guide pins (Figure 68)
used on disc brake assemblies of vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002 be installed before installing caliper. If the guide pins are being replaced, refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to remove and install guide pins.

If old guide pins (Figure 67)
are being replaced with the new guide pins (Figure 68) . Pull guide pin boots (Item 4) off anchor plate (Item 1) or old guide pins and check for damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, they must be replaced. If guide pin boots are not damaged or defective, wash them in soapy water and dry them. Once again, after the guide pin boots have been cleaned and dried, inspect them for damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, they must be replaced. Refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to remove and install guide pin boots.

Also, visually inspect rotor (Item 5) for scoring, warping, cracks, bluing, heat spots or other damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, repair or replace as required. Refer to ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY, Remove
and ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY, Install
.

Figure 67. Leading Guide Pin and Trailing Guide Pin before June 3, 2002
Figure 68. Leading Guide Pin and Trailing Guide Pin with Rubber Bushing after June 3, 2002

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 69 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: If old disc brake pads were removed and are being reinstalled, position inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2) onto anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 3) with the lining facing toward the rotor (Item 4), driver side rear brake shown.

caution.para:
The HX-7A1-EE inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2, Figure 69)
are not interchangeable. The word "FORWARD" and the "ARROW" markings on the brake pad backing plate show forward rotation direction of the rotor (Item 4, Figure 69) . The arrow MUST point in the forward rotor rotation direction (Figure 70) . The optional HX-402-EE and SOFTER lining brake pads inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Item 4, Figure 59)
are interchangeable between the inner and outer locations.

figure.caption: Figure 69. Install Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads
Figure 70. Install Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads with Arrow in Forward Rotor Rotation Direction

step1.para:
If new disc brake pads are being installed, refer to DISC BRAKE PADS, Install
.

caution.para:
Be sure that the correct caliper mounting bolt, torque sequence and torque value is used during caliper installation. Vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002 used caliper hex mounting bolts M12-1.75 x 30 mm long, coarse thread, yellow/gold color (Figure 71)
used with leading and trailing guide pins that were the same. Vehicles manufactured after June 3, 2002 use a caliper hex flanged mounting bolt M12-1.25 x 40 mm long, fine thread, dark-gray/black color (Figure 71)
used with new leading guide pin and trailing guide pin, new trailing guide pin has a rubber bushing. When performing service to vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002, it is recommended to replace old guide pins that are the same with the new leading and trailing guide pins along with the new hex flanged bolts.

important.para: Check new hex flanged mounting bolts for adhesive patch (Figure 71) , if no adhesive patch is found, apply a small patch of liquid loctite 2440 to the area indicated as adhesive patch in (Figure 71) . For best loctite 2440 performance, surfaces should be clean and free of grease. Loctite should be applied to the bolt in sufficient quantity to fill all engaged threads. Loctite develops usable strength within 1 hour and full strength at room temperature in 3 hours.

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 72 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Make sure guide pin heads, hex flanged mounting bolts and mating caliper surfaces are dry and void of grease or foreign matter. Position caliper (Item 1) in place at lower mounting and align flat on guide pin head (Item 2) with the flat on caliper guide pin boss (Item 3), then install the new lower (bottom) hex flanged mounting bolt (Item 4) securing the caliper to the anchor plate (Item 5). Tighten to finger tight, driver side front brake shown.

figure.caption: Figure 72. Install Caliper onto Anchor Plate and Install Lower Hex Flanged Mounting Bolt

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 73 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Carefully rotate caliper (Item 1) closed about the new lower (bottom) hex flanged mounting bolt and guide pin (Items 2 and 3).

Align flat on upper (top) guide pin head (Item 4) with the flat on caliper upper (top) guide pin boss (Item 5). Use care when positioning caliper (Item 1) over the disc brake pads, rotor and upper (top) guide pin head (Items 6, 7 and 8) to avoid tearing, cutting or dislodging piston boots or guide pin boot (Items 9 and 10), driver side front brake shown.
Hold caliper (Item 1) in closed position with upper (top) guide pin boss hole aligned with threads in upper guide pin (Item 8), driver side front brake shown.
Install upper (top) hex flanged mounting bolt (Item 11) securing the caliper (Item 1) to the anchor plate (Item 12). Tighten to finger tight, driver side front brake shown.

figure.caption: Figure 73. Rotate Caliper Closed about Lower Hex Flanged Mounting Bolt and Install Upper Hex Flanged Mounting Bolt

calloutgroup.callout1: 5. CALIPER UPPER GUIDE PIN BOSS FLAT

caution.para:
When both caliper mounting bolts (Items 1 and 2, Figure 74)
have been loosened or removed, it is important to tighten the caliper mounting bolts in the proper sequence. Increased brake drag may result from not tightening in proper sequence.

For FRONT brakes, upper (top) caliper mounting bolt (Item 1, Figure 74)
should be tightened first, then tighten lower (bottom) caliper mounting bolt (Item 2, Figure 74) .

For REAR brakes, lower caliper mounting bolt (Item 2, Figure 74)
should be tightened first, then tighten upper caliper mounting bolt (Item 1, Figure 74) . Use the tighten sequence and torque requirements in step 11 or step 12 below:

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 74
for Items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para: If servicing disc brakes on vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002 that have NOT had the leading and trailing guide pins replaced, tighten the caliper mounting bolts as follows:

step2.para: For FRONT brakes, upper (top) mounting bolt (Item 1) should be tightened first, tighten to 70 to 80 ft-lbs. (95 to 108 N•m). Then tighten lower (bottom) mounting bolt (Item 2), tighten to 70 to 80 ft-lbs. (95 to 108 N•m).

For REAR brakes, lower (bottom) mounting bolt (Item 3) should be tightened first, tighten to 70 to 80 ft-lbs. (95 to 108 N•m). Then tighten upper (top) mounting bolt (Item 4), tighten to 70 to 80 ft-lbs. (95 to 108 N•m).

step1.para: If servicing disc brakes on vehicles manufactured before June 3, 2002 that have had the leading and trailing guide pins replaced, tighten the caliper mounting bolts as follows:

step2.para: For FRONT brakes, upper (top) mounting bolt (Item 1) should be tightened first, tighten to 93 to 107 ft-lbs. (126 to 145 N•m). Then tighten lower (bottom) mounting bolt (Item 2), tighten to 93 to 107 ft-lbs. (126 to 145 N•m).

For REAR brakes, lower (bottom) mounting bolt (Item 3) should be tightened first, tighten to 93 to 107 ft-lbs. (126 to 145 N•m). Then tighten upper (top) mounting bolt (Item 4), tighten to 93 to 107 ft-lbs. (126 to 145 N•m).

step1.para: Position brake line hose (Item 3) at the lower hydraulic brake line port (Item 4) on the caliper (Item 5) and install hydraulic brake line hex fitting (Item 6) into the caliper. Tighten to 7.5 to 15 ft-lbs. (10 to 20 N•m).
Position brake line retaining clip (Item 7) on the caliper (Item 5) and install hex head bolt (Item 8). Tighten to 18 to 22 ft-lbs. (24 to 30 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 74. Tightening Upper and Lower Caliper Mounting Bolts in Proper Sequence

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 75 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: On front axles only, position brake line retaining clip (Item 2) over threaded stud (Item 3) on the steering knuckle hose support bracket (Item 4), make sure the brake line hose is not pinched or kinked. Install hex nut and lock washer (Item 1). Tighten to 115 to 140 in-lbs. (13 to 16 N•m).

figure.caption: Figure 75. Install Brake Line Retaining Clip and Install Hex Nut and Flat Washer

step1.para:
Install wheel (tire and rim) on vehicle and remove floor stands. Refer to GROUPS 17 - WHEELS in the Master Service Manual for proper wheel installation. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications based on mounting hardware size and thread type.

note.para: When installing the wheel (tire and rim) on disc brake axles, make sure the tire valve stem clears the brake caliper. The use of a valve stem retainer or a tire manufacturer's stem forming tool are the only acceptable methods of obtaining clearance when necessary.

step1.para: Check the master cylinder reservoir and fill if necessary. Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the Master Service Manual for proper brake fluid.
After any brake service, be sure to test brakes prior to returning vehicle to service. A firm pedal should be felt during brake application.

If necessary, bleed brakes. Refer to BLEEDING INSTRUCTIONS
.
